perturbation.original_text: The total sum of non-paid invoices (estimated to be approximately $80,000) payable to Marv Enterprises, LLC, previously owed by Premier to Marv up until the effective date of this Agreement, payable in total by no later than July 20, 2020.
perturbation.changed_text: The total sum of non-paid invoices (estimated to be approximately $80,000) payable to Marv Enterprises, LLC, previously owed by Premier to Marv up until the effective date of this Agreement, payable in total at the company's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the due date to "at the company's discretion" introduces a legal contradiction as it violates laws requiring timely payment for services rendered.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Pennsylvania Wage Payment and Collection Law
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified text contradicts 43 P.S. § 260.3, which mandates specific deadlines for wage payments, including final payments upon termination. Replacing the fixed deadline with "at the company's discretion" removes the legal obligation for timely payment.

perturbation.original_text: Within thirty (30) days after the end of each quarterly period ending on March 31st, June 30th, September 30th, or December 31st, commencing with the one-year anniversary of the effective date of this Agreement, THI shall furnish to Marv a statement certified by a responsible official of the Licensee showing in a manner acceptable to Marv: i. all Licensed Products which were sold, leased or put into use during such quarterly period by THI or any of its Related Companies, the gross sales received for the Licensed Products, and the Fair Market Values of such Licensed Products; ii. all services performed by THI or any of its Related Companies that directly or indirectly used Licensed Product, the gross sales received by the services, and the Fair Market Value of such services; 2 iii. the amount of royalty payable thereon, and iv. if no Licensed Product has been so sold, leased or put into use or if no services have been performed, the statement shall show that fact.
perturbation.changed_text: Within ninety (90) days after the end of each quarterly period ending on March 31st, June 30th, September 30th, or December 31st, commencing with the one-year anniversary of the effective date of this Agreement, THI shall furnish to Marv a statement certified by a responsible official of the Licensee showing in a manner acceptable to Marv: i. all Licensed Products which were sold, leased or put into use during such quarterly period by THI or any of its Related Companies, the gross sales received for the Licensed Products, and the Fair Market Values of such Licensed Products; ii. all services performed by THI or any of its Related Companies that directly or indirectly used Licensed Product, the gross sales received by the services, and the Fair Market Value of such services; 2 iii. the amount of royalty payable thereon, and iv. if no Licensed Product has been so sold, leased or put into use or if no services have been performed, the statement shall show that fact.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the reporting deadline to 90 days may conflict with standard business practices and accounting regulations that require more frequent reporting, especially for publicly traded companies. While there isn't a specific law mandating a 30-day reporting period in all cases, extending it excessively could create issues with financial transparency.
perturbation.law_explanation: 17 CFR § 240.13a-13 requires quarterly reports to be filed by publicly traded companies. While it doesn't specify an exact number of days, the regulation implies that information should be current. Extending the reporting period to 90 days may make it difficult for the company to meet its obligations under securities law.

perturbation.original_text: Affirmation of payment must be received by Marv within fourteen (14) days of the mailing date of the notice or the THI shall be deemed to have denied payment.
perturbation.changed_text: Affirmation of payment must be received by Marv within five (5) days of the mailing date of the notice or the THI shall be deemed to have denied payment.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the affirmation period to 5 days could be considered unreasonable and contradict the principles of good faith and fair dealing, especially if the licensee is located internationally.
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified text contradicts UCC § 1-304 because shortening the affirmation period to 5 days may not allow THI a reasonable opportunity to evaluate the IP costs and respond. This could be seen as a breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, which requires parties to act honestly and reasonably in the performance and enforcement of contracts.
